question:
Under whose reign was the maximum number of books in Persian on classical Indian Music written?

SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The maximum number of Persian-language books on classical Indian music were written during the reign of Aurangzeb.
  • Though he is often portrayed as unsupportive of music, many scholars and court musicians documented musical knowledge during his time.
  • This paradoxical outcome occurred because, after Aurangzeb's disapproval of court performances, musicians turned to writing, preserving theory in textual form.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Aurangzeb.

Additional Information:

  • Notable works from this period include “Risala-i-Ragadarpana” and other treatises that systematised Indian music in Persian.
  • Aurangzeb himself was trained in music in his youth but later banned music performances at court, citing religious reasons.
  • Despite restrictions, the scholarly output on music actually increased during his rule as a means of preservation.

question:
Which Mughal Emperor has attempted to vandalise the Kailash Temple at Ellora?

SSC MTS 02/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The Kailash Temple at Ellora, a rock-cut marvel dedicated to Lord Shiva, faced vandalism attempts during Aurangzeb’s reign.
  • Historical accounts and archaeological evidence suggest that Aurangzeb ordered partial destruction of several Hindu temples, including parts of the Kailash Temple.
  • Though the temple survived due to its solid monolithic structure, signs of attempted damage are still visible.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Aurangzeb.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb followed a more orthodox Islamic policy compared to his predecessors and issued decrees against idol worship and temple construction.
  • Despite this, the Kailash Temple at Ellora remains one of the finest surviving examples of ancient Indian rock architecture.
  • Many other temples across the Deccan and northern India also faced similar threats during his campaigns.

question:
Who among the following Mughal emperors assumed the title Alamgir, World Conqueror?

SSC MTS 10/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The Mughal emperor who took the title “Alamgir”, meaning “World Conqueror”, was Aurangzeb.
  • He assumed this title after ascending the throne in 1658, symbolising his ambition to expand and control the entire Indian subcontinent.
  • The title reflected his military zeal and deeply rooted orthodox religious ideology.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Aurangzeb.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb's full title was “Abul Muzaffar Muhi-ud-Din Muhammad Aurangzeb Alamgir”.
  • His reign marked the greatest territorial extent of the Mughal Empire, though it also led to internal strife.
  • Despite military success, his rigid policies led to decline in administrative cohesion and rebellions.

question:
Which of the following architecture is a memorial of Aurangzeb's wife, Dilras Banu Begum?

SSC MTS 19/05/2023 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Bibi Ka Maqbara is a mausoleum built in memory of Dilras Banu Begum, the wife of Mughal emperor Aurangzeb.
  • It was commissioned by her son, Prince Azam Shah, around 1660 AD in Aurangabad, Maharashtra.
  • The structure bears a striking resemblance to the Taj Mahal, earning it the nickname “Taj of the Deccan”.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Bibi Ka Maqbara.

Additional Information:

  • Dilras Banu Begum was an Iranian princess from the Safavid dynasty and Aurangzeb’s chief consort.
  • The maqbara was constructed using marble and basalt, but on a relatively modest scale compared to the Taj Mahal.
  • Though Aurangzeb was known for his austerity, this tomb remains a notable example of late Mughal architecture.

question:
Mughal ruler, Aurangzeb died in which year?

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• Mughal emperor Aurangzeb died in the year 1707 after ruling for nearly 49 years.
  • His death marked the end of the last powerful Mughal ruler, as the empire began to decline rapidly thereafter.
  • He passed away in Ahmednagar (present-day Maharashtra) during a military campaign in the Deccan.
  • Hence, the correct answer is 1707.

Additional Information:

  • After Aurangzeb’s death, a war of succession broke out among his sons, weakening the central authority.
  • He was buried in Khuldabad, near Aurangabad, in a modest grave as per his wish for simplicity.
  • The Mughal Empire began to face invasions, regional uprisings, and loss of control soon after his death.

question:
Who was considered as the last powerful Mughal ruler of India?

SSC CGL 03/12/2022 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Aurangzeb is regarded as the last powerful Mughal ruler of India.
  • Under his rule, the Mughal Empire reached its greatest territorial extent, covering almost the entire Indian subcontinent.
  • Despite this expansion, his orthodox policies and prolonged military campaigns weakened the empire internally.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Aurangzeb.

Additional Information:

  • After Aurangzeb’s death in 1707, the empire began to fragment rapidly due to internal conflicts and external invasions.
  • His successors were largely ineffective and puppet rulers, with real power shifting to regional kingdoms and the British.
  • Aurangzeb’s reign marked both the peak and the beginning of the decline of the Mughal Empire.

question:
Bijapur was annexed Aurangzeb in which year?

SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The Bijapur Sultanate, one of the major Deccan kingdoms, was annexed by Aurangzeb in 1686.
  • Aurangzeb personally led the military campaign against Bijapur as part of his long-term strategy to consolidate Mughal power in the Deccan.
  • After a prolonged siege, the city was captured, marking a major victory for the Mughals.
  • Hence, the correct answer is 1686.

Additional Information:

  • The annexation of Bijapur was followed by the capture of Golconda in 1687, completing Aurangzeb’s Deccan conquest.
  • These campaigns drained the Mughal treasury and resources, contributing to the empire’s later decline.
  • Despite military success, continuous warfare weakened central authority and administration.

question:
Which of the following is an example of Mughal architecture under Aurangzeb?

SSC MTS 06/07/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• The Moti Masjid in Delhi, also known as the Pearl Mosque, was built by Aurangzeb inside the Red Fort complex.
  • It is one of the few notable examples of Mughal architecture commissioned by Aurangzeb, who generally followed a more austere lifestyle.
  • The mosque is made of white marble and is known for its simplicity and elegance, reflecting his orthodox religious beliefs.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Moti Masjid, Delhi.

Additional Information:

  • The Moti Masjid in Delhi was constructed around 1659–1660 CE, shortly after Aurangzeb’s accession to the throne.
  • Unlike his predecessors, Aurangzeb focused less on grand architecture and more on religious buildings.
  • Other famous monuments like the Taj Mahal and Jama Masjid were built by Shah Jahan, and Qutub Minar was constructed during the Delhi Sultanate.

question:
Who among the following was defeated by Aurangzeb in the Battle of Deorai?

SSC MTS 20/10/2021 (Afternoon)
solution:
• The Battle of Deorai (1659) was a decisive encounter between Aurangzeb and Dara Shikoh, the eldest son of Shah Jahan.
  • It was the final battle in the Mughal war of succession following Shah Jahan’s illness.
  • Aurangzeb defeated Dara Shikoh, captured him, and later ordered his execution.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Dara Shikoh.

Additional Information:

  • The battle took place near Ajmer, in present-day Rajasthan.
  • Dara Shikoh was known for his liberal and Sufi-influenced ideas, which were in contrast to Aurangzeb’s orthodox stance.
  • With Dara eliminated, Aurangzeb became the undisputed emperor of the Mughal Empire.

question:
Who is the author of the book 'Tarikh-i Dilkusha'?

SSC CGL 17/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• The book ‘Tarikh-i-Dilkusha’ was written by Bhimsen, a Mughal-era official and historian.
  • He served under Aurangzeb and chronicled various events of the emperor’s military campaigns, especially in the Deccan region.
  • The text is considered an important historical source that offers insights into Mughal administration and warfare during Aurangzeb’s reign.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Bhimsen.

Additional Information:

  • Tarikh-i-Dilkusha is written in Persian and presents both eyewitness accounts and administrative observations.
  • Unlike imperial chronicles, Bhimsen's account carries a civilian and personal perspective, making it valuable for historical analysis.
  • Panini, Sushruta, and Charaka were ancient Indian scholars unrelated to Mughal-era history.

question: Aurangzeb ascended the Mughal throne in the year:
solution:
• Aurangzeb ascended the Mughal throne in 1658 after defeating his brothers in the war of succession.
  • He deposed his father Shah Jahan, who had fallen ill, and imprisoned him in Agra Fort.
  • His coronation marked the beginning of a 49-year reign, the longest among Mughal emperors.
  • Hence, the correct answer is 1658.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb’s formal coronation took place at Delhi under the title “Alamgir”.
  • His reign was marked by military expansion, religious orthodoxy, and growing internal unrest.
  • Though powerful, his rule laid the groundwork for the decline of the Mughal Empire.

question: What was Aurangzeb’s regnal title after becoming emperor?
solution:
• After ascending the Mughal throne in 1658, Aurangzeb adopted the regnal title “Alamgir”, which means “World Conqueror”.
  • The title reflected his imperial ambition and orthodox vision for expanding and purifying the Mughal Empire.
  • “Alamgir” became a central part of his identity throughout his reign.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Alamgir.

Additional Information:

  • His full imperial title was Abul Muzaffar Muhi-ud-Din Muhammad Aurangzeb Alamgir.
  • The title distinguished him from previous rulers who used titles like Shahenshah or Padshah without such aggressive connotations.
  • “Alamgir” symbolised his militant expansionist policy across the Indian subcontinent.

question: Aurangzeb came to power after defeating which of his brothers in the war of succession?
option_4: All of the above
solution:
• Aurangzeb came to power after a bloody war of succession following the illness of his father, Shah Jahan.
  • He defeated all three of his brothers: Dara Shikoh, Shah Shuja, and Murad Baksh, to claim the Mughal throne.
  • Dara Shikoh was his main rival and was defeated in the Battle of Deorai, later executed.
  • Hence, the correct answer is All of the above.

Additional Information:

  • Murad Baksh initially allied with Aurangzeb but was later imprisoned and executed by him.
  • Shah Shuja fled towards Bengal and eventually disappeared in Arakan (modern-day Myanmar), likely killed.
  • The war of succession lasted from 1657 to 1659 and ended with Aurangzeb's undisputed rule.

question: Dara Shikoh was known for his support to:
option_3: Sufi philosophy and Hindu-Muslim unity
solution:
• Dara Shikoh, the eldest son of Shah Jahan, was known for his liberal religious outlook and promotion of Sufi philosophy.
  • He actively supported interfaith dialogue, particularly between Hinduism and Islam, aiming to bridge the religious divide.
  • Dara translated several Upanishads and the Bhagavad Gita into Persian, believing they shared common truths with Islamic mysticism.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Sufi philosophy and Hindu-Muslim unity.

Additional Information:

  • His famous work, “Majma-ul-Bahrain” (The Mingling of Two Oceans), highlights the syncretic ideas he supported.
  • Dara Shikoh was a follower of the Qadiri Sufi order and opposed to Aurangzeb’s orthodox Islamic stance.
  • His inclusive approach was one reason he lost support among conservative Muslim nobles, leading to his downfall.

question: Aurangzeb reimposed which religious tax on non-Muslims that Akbar had abolished?
solution:
• Aurangzeb reimposed the Jizya tax on non-Muslims in 1679, which had been abolished by Akbar in the late 16th century.
  • Jizya was a religious tax levied on non-Muslims (primarily Hindus) under Islamic rule in return for protection and exemption from military service.
  • Its reimposition signalled Aurangzeb’s shift towards orthodox Islamic governance and alienated a large portion of his Hindu subjects.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Jizya.

Additional Information:

  • The reintroduction of Jizya led to widespread resentment, particularly among Rajputs, Marathas, and merchants.
  • Akbar had abolished it to promote religious tolerance and integration within his empire.
  • Aurangzeb's decision reflected a reversal of Akbar’s liberal policies and deepened communal divisions during his reign.

question: Aurangzeb banned which of the following activities at his court?
option_2: Music and dance performances
option_4: All of the above
solution:
• Aurangzeb was known for his strict adherence to orthodox Islamic principles, which led him to ban several cultural and recreational activities at his court.
  • He banned wine drinking, considering it against Islamic law.
  • He also prohibited music and dance performances, which had been central to Mughal court life under rulers like Akbar and Jahangir.
  • Even court poetry and artistic indulgences were discouraged during his reign.
  • Hence, the correct answer is All of the above.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb disbanded the imperial music department and dismissed court musicians.
  • Despite the ban, some musicians turned to writing treatises, preserving musical knowledge.
  • These cultural restrictions marked a sharp contrast with the rich artistic patronage of his predecessors.

question: Which Sikh Guru was executed on Aurangzeb’s orders in 1675?
solution:
• Guru Tegh Bahadur, the ninth Sikh Guru, was executed on the orders of Aurangzeb in 1675.
  • He was arrested and brought to Delhi for refusing to convert to Islam and for defending the religious freedom of Hindus in Kashmir.
  • He was beheaded in Chandni Chowk, making him a martyr for the cause of religious liberty.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Guru Tegh Bahadur.

Additional Information:

  • Guru Tegh Bahadur’s martyrdom is considered a turning point in Sikh history, inspiring the community to militarise under Guru Gobind Singh.
  • He stood up against religious persecution and is remembered for his sacrifice for others' faiths.
  • His execution deepened the rift between the Sikhs and the Mughal Empire.

question: Aurangzeb's longest military campaigns were in which region?
solution:
• Aurangzeb’s longest and most exhausting military campaigns were in the Deccan region of South India.
  • He spent nearly 25 years (from around 1681 to 1707) in the Deccan, attempting to annex kingdoms like Bijapur and Golconda and suppress the Maratha resistance.
  • These prolonged campaigns drained the Mughal treasury, overextended the empire, and weakened central control.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Deccan.

Additional Information:

  • The Deccan campaigns included battles against Shivaji’s successors, the Adil Shahi (Bijapur), and Qutb Shahi (Golconda) dynasties.
  • Despite military success, Aurangzeb failed to establish lasting control over the region.
  • His death in 1707 in the Deccan marked the beginning of the empire’s fragmentation.

question: Aurangzeb annexed which Deccan sultanate after a long campaign?
solution:
• Aurangzeb annexed both Bijapur and Golconda, the two major Deccan Sultanates, after prolonged military campaigns.
  • Bijapur was annexed in 1686 and Golconda in 1687, marking the culmination of Aurangzeb’s efforts to bring the entire Deccan under Mughal control.
  • These victories significantly expanded the empire but came at a high cost in terms of resources, time, and stability.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Both (a) and (b).

Additional Information:

  • The Adil Shahi dynasty of Bijapur and the Qutb Shahi dynasty of Golconda were the last major Islamic sultanates in the Deccan.
  • The sieges involved long warfare and betrayal, including the famous bribery of Golconda’s gatekeeper during the final assault.
  • Despite military success, resistance from the Marathas continued, making it difficult for Aurangzeb to maintain effective control.

question: Aurangzeb captured the Golconda fort in:
solution:
• Aurangzeb captured the Golconda Fort in 1687 after a prolonged siege against the Qutb Shahi dynasty.
  • Although the fort was well-defended, Mughal forces finally succeeded through military pressure and internal betrayal.
  • This marked the end of the Qutb Shahi rule and brought the rich diamond mines of Golconda under Mughal control.
  • Hence, the correct answer is 1686 (as per question’s options, although historically the fall occurred in early 1687 after the 1686 siege).

Additional Information:

  • The Siege of Golconda lasted for about eight months, showing the fort’s strong defences.
  • The betrayal by an insider, Abdullah Khan, enabled the Mughals to breach the fort.
  • After this conquest, Aurangzeb’s control over the entire Deccan region was nearly complete.

question: Which Maratha ruler was imprisoned by Aurangzeb and later escaped from Agra Fort?
solution:
• Shivaji, the founder of the Maratha Empire, was imprisoned by Aurangzeb in 1666 at the Agra Fort.
  • He had visited the Mughal court under a diplomatic agreement but was insulted and placed under house arrest by Aurangzeb.
  • Shivaji famously escaped using fruit baskets, in one of the most legendary episodes in Indian history.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Shivaji.

Additional Information:

  • Shivaji’s escape was a major blow to Mughal prestige and boosted Maratha morale.
  • After his return to Maharashtra, he continued to challenge Mughal authority.
  • This incident marked a turning point in Mughal–Maratha relations, intensifying the rivalry.

question: The Mughal-Maratha conflict under Aurangzeb started due to:
option_1: Shivaji’s attack on Surat
option_4: French support to Marathas
solution:
• The Mughal-Maratha conflict under Aurangzeb was triggered primarily by Shivaji’s raid on Surat in 1664, one of the richest port cities under Mughal control.
  • The raid humiliated the Mughal Empire and challenged its authority in the Deccan, provoking a strong reaction from Aurangzeb.
  • This act set off a series of battles and confrontations, leading to decades of Mughal-Maratha warfare.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Shivaji’s attack on Surat.

Additional Information:

  • The plundering of Surat was aimed at acquiring wealth to fund Maratha expansion.
  • Following the raid, Aurangzeb dispatched generals like Shaista Khan and Jai Singh to subdue Shivaji.
  • Despite strong Mughal retaliation, Shivaji’s guerrilla tactics made it difficult for the Mughals to achieve lasting victory.

question: Aurangzeb’s religious policy can best be described as:
option_4: Focused on Hindu-Muslim unity
solution:
• Aurangzeb’s religious policy is best described as rigid and orthodox, reflecting his commitment to Sunni Islamic principles.
  • He reimposed Jizya tax on non-Muslims, banned music, dance, and other cultural practices, and destroyed several Hindu temples during his reign.
  • His policies marked a departure from the tolerant and inclusive approaches of Akbar and even Jahangir.
  • Hence, the correct answer is rigid and orthodox.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb ended several practices started by earlier emperors, such as celebrating Hindu festivals at court.
  • His religious rigidity led to resistance from Sikhs, Marathas, Rajputs, and other regional groups.
  • These policies contributed to growing internal unrest and fragmentation of the Mughal Empire.

question: Aurangzeb’s rule saw the rise of which Sikh military group?
solution:
• During Aurangzeb’s rule, the Khalsa was founded by Guru Gobind Singh in 1699 as a militant Sikh order to defend religious freedom and oppose Mughal oppression.
  • The formation of the Khalsa marked a transformation of the Sikh community into a military and spiritual collective.
  • This was a direct response to the execution of Guru Tegh Bahadur and growing persecution under Aurangzeb.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Khalsa.

Additional Information:

  • The Khalsa was initiated at Anandpur Sahib, where Guru Gobind Singh baptised the Panj Pyare (Five Beloved Ones).
  • Members of the Khalsa followed a strict moral code and wore the Five Ks (Kesh, Kara, Kanga, Kachera, Kirpan).
  • The rise of Khalsa gave the Sikh movement a strong military identity, leading to prolonged resistance against Mughal rule.

question: Aurangzeb issued farman to destroy several temples. One of the most prominent was:
solution:
• Aurangzeb issued a farman (royal decree) ordering the destruction of several Hindu temples during his reign, as part of his religiously orthodox policies.
  • Among the most prominent was the Kashi Vishwanath Temple in Varanasi, one of the holiest temples dedicated to Lord Shiva.
  • In 1669, the temple was destroyed, and the Gyanvapi Mosque was constructed on its site.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Kashi Vishwanath.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb’s temple destruction orders were often linked to political rebellion or religious justification.
  • The demolition of Kashi Vishwanath had symbolic and strategic importance, aimed at weakening Hindu religious centres.
  • Many temples in Mathura and Ujjain also faced similar destruction under his rule.

question: Which Rajput ruler continued to resist Aurangzeb’s authority in Mewar?
solution:
• Rana Raj Singh, the ruler of Mewar, was one of the most notable Rajput kings who resisted Aurangzeb’s authority.
  • He strongly opposed Aurangzeb’s centralising and religiously intolerant policies, particularly the reimposition of Jizya and temple destruction.
  • Rana Raj Singh provided support to rebel leaders, including Shivaji and other anti-Mughal forces, maintaining Mewar’s independent stance.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Rana Raj Singh.

Additional Information:

  • Rana Raj Singh ruled Mewar during the mid to late 17th century and upheld the legacy of Rajput autonomy.
  • His defiance forced Aurangzeb to launch campaigns into the Aravalli region, which met with limited success.
  • The resistance of Mewar under his leadership became a symbol of Rajput pride and resilience against Mughal imperialism.

question: Aurangzeb’s court official and historian who wrote Alamgirnama was:
solution:
• Mirza Muhammad Kazim, a court official during Aurangzeb’s reign, authored the Alamgirnama, which serves as an official chronicle of the early years of Aurangzeb's rule.
  • The book was written in Persian and covers the first ten years of Aurangzeb’s reign (1658–1667).
  • It documents significant events including military campaigns, administrative actions, and court proceedings.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Mirza Muhammad Kazim.

Additional Information:

  • The Alamgirnama was commissioned by Aurangzeb himself and follows the tradition of court-sponsored histories like Akbarnama and Padshahnama.
  • The chronicle ends in 1667, after which Khafi Khan’s works provide later accounts of Aurangzeb’s reign.
  • Though official in tone, Alamgirnama is a vital source for understanding Aurangzeb’s early policies and imperial mindset.

question: Aurangzeb shifted his court to the Deccan during his late reign and ruled from:
solution:
• In the later years of his reign, Aurangzeb shifted his court to the Deccan to directly oversee prolonged military campaigns against the Marathas and Deccan Sultanates.
  • He ruled from Aurangabad, which became the de facto capital of the Mughal Empire during that period.
  • From here, he managed the empire’s southern affairs until his death in 1707.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Aurangabad.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangabad was strategically located for operations against Bijapur, Golconda, and Maratha territories.
  • Despite the shift, he never returned to Delhi and died in the Deccan, marking the final phase of Mughal expansion.
  • His body was buried in Khuldabad, near Aurangabad, in accordance with his wish for a simple grave.

question: Which Mughal prince rebelled against Aurangzeb and declared himself emperor in Deccan?
solution:
• Prince Akbar, the son of Aurangzeb, rebelled against his father in 1681 and attempted to declare himself emperor in the Deccan.
  • He allied with the Rajputs, particularly Rana Raj Singh of Mewar, to challenge Aurangzeb’s authority.
  • The rebellion failed, and Akbar eventually fled to Persia, where he spent the rest of his life in exile.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Akbar (his son).

Additional Information:

  • This rebellion occurred during Aurangzeb’s Deccan campaigns, complicating his efforts to consolidate power in the south.
  • Akbar’s alliance with Rajputs shows the fractures within the Mughal royal family and growing dissatisfaction with Aurangzeb’s rule.
  • Unlike his namesake (Akbar the Great), Prince Akbar could never gain widespread support and remained in exile until his death.

question: Aurangzeb’s Deccan policy led to:
option_1: Expansion of Mughal rule to Sri Lanka
option_2: Stability in South India
option_3: Overstretching of the empire and administrative exhaustion
option_4: Peace treaties with Portuguese
solution:
• Aurangzeb’s Deccan policy, which involved prolonged military campaigns against the Marathas, Bijapur, and Golconda, resulted in the overstretching of Mughal resources.
  • The empire was drawn into a constant state of warfare, requiring massive funds and administrative focus far from the imperial core.
  • This led to administrative exhaustion, a weakened central authority, and contributed significantly to the decline of the Mughal Empire.
  • Hence, the correct answer is overstretching of the empire and administrative exhaustion.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb spent nearly 25 years in the Deccan, never returning to Delhi.
  • The Marathas continued guerrilla resistance, preventing full control.
  • These prolonged wars drained the treasury, reduced revenue collection efficiency, and sparked regional rebellions.

question: Aurangzeb died in:
solution:
• Aurangzeb died in 1707 at the age of 88, after a reign of nearly 49 years, the longest among all Mughal emperors.
  • He passed away in Ahmednagar (in present-day Maharashtra) during his prolonged stay in the Deccan, where he had shifted his court.
  • His death marked the beginning of the Mughal Empire’s decline, as it triggered a war of succession and loss of central control.
  • Hence, the correct answer is 1707.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb was buried in a simple grave at Khuldabad, near Aurangabad, according to his own wishes.
  • After his death, his sons Azam Shah, Kam Bakhsh, and Muazzam (later Bahadur Shah I) fought for the throne.
  • The central authority weakened, and regional powers like the Marathas, Sikhs, and Rajputs began to assert greater independence.

question: The immediate successor of Aurangzeb was:
solution:
• After Aurangzeb’s death in 1707, a war of succession broke out among his sons — Azam Shah, Kam Bakhsh, and Muazzam.
  • Muazzam emerged victorious and ascended the throne as Bahadur Shah I.
  • He ruled from 1707 to 1712 and attempted to stabilise the empire, though central authority continued to weaken.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Bahadur Shah I.

Additional Information:

  • Bahadur Shah I was also known as Shah Alam I.
  • He adopted a more conciliatory approach toward the Rajputs, Marathas, and Sikhs compared to his father.
  • His short reign was marked by temporary peace efforts, but the empire remained fragmented and unstable.

question: Aurangzeb ruled for how many years?
solution:
• Aurangzeb ruled for 49 years, from 1658 to 1707, making his reign the longest in Mughal history.
  • He ascended the throne after defeating his brothers in a war of succession and ruled until his death in the Deccan.
  • His reign witnessed the greatest territorial expansion of the Mughal Empire, but also laid the foundation for its eventual decline.
  • Hence, the correct answer is 49.

Additional Information:

  • Despite initial military success, his prolonged Deccan campaigns and rigid religious policies overburdened the empire.
  • His successors could not maintain the vast empire he left behind.
  • Aurangzeb's reign is seen as the high point in terms of size, but a turning point toward decline in administration and unity.

question: What was the impact of Aurangzeb’s long rule on the Mughal Empire?
option_3: Military expansion and over-centralization
solution:
• Aurangzeb’s long rule (1658–1707) led to significant military expansion, particularly in the Deccan region, which brought the Mughal Empire to its greatest territorial extent.
  • However, this expansion came with a cost — his highly centralised and rigid administration struggled to manage such a vast empire.
  • The continuous warfare, especially in the south, caused administrative strain, economic exhaustion, and rebellions in various regions.
  • Hence, the correct answer is military expansion and over-centralization.

Additional Information:

  • His orthodox religious policies and alienation of non-Muslim communities further weakened internal cohesion.
  • The empire became too large to govern effectively, and after his death, it began to fragment rapidly.
  • Aurangzeb's policies, though expansionist, ultimately undermined the stability of the Mughal state.

question: Aurangzeb’s revenue system was largely based on:
option_4: British land tenure system
solution:
• Aurangzeb’s revenue system was largely based on the Zabti system introduced by Todar Mal, the revenue minister of Akbar.
  • The Zabti system involved measuring the land and fixing a standard cash assessment based on the average produce of past years.
  • Though Aurangzeb followed Islamic principles in governance, he retained many administrative structures from Akbar’s era, including revenue collection methods.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Todar Mal’s Zabti.

Additional Information:

  • The Zabti system was part of Akbar’s Dahsala system, and remained effective due to its systematic and standardised approach.
  • Aurangzeb also faced challenges like war expenses and declining productivity, but continued to rely on existing frameworks.
  • The Jagirdari system was more related to land assignments for officials, not direct assessment like Zabti.

question: The execution of which Maratha ruler by Aurangzeb led to intensified Maratha resistance?
solution:
• Sambhaji, the eldest son of Shivaji, was captured by Mughal forces in 1689 during Aurangzeb’s Deccan campaign.
  • He was tortured and executed on Aurangzeb’s orders for refusing to convert to Islam and for resisting Mughal authority.
  • His brutal execution angered the Maratha community and became a rallying point for intensified resistance against the Mughal Empire.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Sambhaji.

Additional Information:

  • After Sambhaji’s death, his brother Rajaram continued the resistance by adopting guerrilla warfare tactics.
  • The Marathas became more organised and resilient, eventually leading to the decline of Mughal control in the Deccan.
  • Sambhaji’s martyrdom is remembered as a symbol of Maratha pride and defiance.

question: Which Mughal emperor’s reign marked the maximum territorial expansion of the empire?
solution:
• The Mughal Empire reached its greatest territorial extent during the reign of Aurangzeb.
  • Under his rule, the empire stretched from Kashmir in the north to Tamil Nadu in the south, and from Afghanistan in the west to Bengal in the east.
  • This expansion was achieved through prolonged military campaigns, especially in the Deccan region, where Aurangzeb annexed Bijapur and Golconda and fought against the Marathas.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Aurangzeb.

Additional Information:

  • Although the empire was largest under Aurangzeb, this expansion came at the cost of administrative strain and internal unrest.
  • Unlike Akbar’s more inclusive governance, Aurangzeb’s orthodox policies alienated many regional powers.
  • After his death in 1707, the vast empire became difficult to manage and began to fragment rapidly.

question: Aurangzeb’s religious policy had what long-term impact on Mughal political unity?
option_2: Weakened religious harmony and alienated subjects
option_3: Led to Persian invasions
solution:
• Aurangzeb’s religious policy was marked by orthodoxy and intolerance, including the reimposition of Jizya tax, destruction of Hindu temples, and exclusion of non-Muslims from high offices.
  • These measures weakened the religious harmony that earlier emperors like Akbar had fostered, and alienated large sections of the population, including Hindus, Rajputs, Sikhs, and Marathas.
  • As a result, the Mughal Empire faced growing rebellions and regional defiance, undermining its political unity in the long term.
  • Hence, the correct answer is weakened religious harmony and alienated subjects.

Additional Information:

  • The Rajput alliance, a key pillar of Mughal strength under Akbar and Jahangir, began to crumble during Aurangzeb’s reign.
  • His execution of Guru Tegh Bahadur and conflict with Shivaji’s Marathas further deepened religious and regional divides.
  • These policies sowed the seeds of disintegration that accelerated after his death.

question: Aurangzeb appointed which famous noble to suppress the Sikhs?
solution:
• Aurangzeb appointed Wazir Khan, the Faujdar (military commander) of Sirhind, to suppress the growing power of the Sikhs under Guru Gobind Singh.
  • Wazir Khan played a brutal role in Mughal-Sikh conflicts, including the execution of Guru Gobind Singh’s young sons, which intensified Sikh resistance.
  • His oppressive actions led to widespread outrage and laid the foundation for continued Sikh military opposition to the Mughal Empire.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Wazir Khan.

Additional Information:

  • The Battle of Chamkaur (1704) and the execution at Sirhind became turning points in Sikh history.
  • Wazir Khan was later killed in 1710 by Banda Singh Bahadur, a Sikh leader who avenged the atrocities committed under Aurangzeb’s orders.
  • The Mughal attempt to crush the Sikhs backfired, leading to the militarisation and consolidation of Sikh power.

question: Aurangzeb's tomb is located in:
solution:
• Aurangzeb’s tomb is located in Aurangabad, specifically at Khuldabad, a town near Aurangabad in present-day Maharashtra.
  • Unlike other Mughal emperors, Aurangzeb chose a simple burial, consistent with his orthodox Islamic beliefs.
  • His tomb is unadorned and modest, built without using imperial funds, reflecting his personal request for simplicity.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Aurangabad.

Additional Information:

  • Aurangzeb died in 1707 during his Deccan campaigns and was buried in Khuldabad, which is also known as the Valley of Saints.
  • The tomb was later enclosed by a marble screen funded by the Nizam of Hyderabad.
  • It remains a significant historical and spiritual site visited by historians and devotees alike.
